author: jvalero

description.text:
Scale 1.04-1.05
Design by sAmgolEE

Warnings
=======
Project is big and consist of many details. So i will use this thing as central hub and post here links to blocks, like "lower part of gearbox" or "frontset". STL's published here is upper part of gearbox.
Warning! You will need engineering skills, deep understanding of airsoft gun internals and really long time with file to ensure smooth operating of gun. I took for me about 1.5 years to design and create working aeg.
Contents
====
Upper gearbox - this part
Lower gearbox - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:461970
Grip - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:462057
Mag holder - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:462840
Hop-up unit and front rail - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:463221
Frontset - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:470987
To be published:
Stock
Stock is removable and attaches to a 20-mm rail, so you already can make an aeg without stock, or attach any picatinny stock.
About
=====
I’ve started this project with inspiration of Scorpion EVO 3 A1, but tried to make TM-compatible parts gun as small, as it could be. Gun is really thin – about 32mm. Overall length is 431mm, barrel – 223mm. Height from bottom of pistol grip to top of upper rail – 173mm. Gun uses standard TM-compatible:
Gears, short-type motor, 223 mm 6.03 barrel, hop-up rubber, tappet plate (v3), nozzle (ak), cylinder, cylinder head(o-ring and nozzle guide only), piston with piston head, spring, spring guide (v2). All other parts are 3d-printed. Cylinder head self-designed as well as gearbox. Pistol grip holds motor, in bottom of pistol grip installed adjustment screw. Hop-up is adjustable and firmly attached to upper part of gearbox to ensure proper co-axial position and enforce cylinder head. In handgrip placed electronic key and 7.4v Li-Po accumulator. Gun uses airsoft MP5 mags.
Rear end of upper gearbox is quick-detachable for easy spring change. Construction of piston guides allows to change piston without gearbox disassembly. Lower part of gearbox holds gears and antireverse latch. Gun has upper and lower Picatinny rails for attachments.
Right now I use 80 meter per second spring, which outputs 78 meter per second with .25g BB’s.
Initially, I’ve planned using 3d printed parts only for prototyping, but ABS seems to be sturdy enough, at least for cqb gun. Until now I’ve shot about 2000 bb’s and plan to go with this gun on local games for testing.

Parts
====
You will need:
  • Lots of m3 nuts and m3 screws (i used big collection of screws from 8 to 40mm long)
  • One m5 screw
  • Plastic AK-type cylinder head
  • AK-type nozzle
  • TM-compatible piston
  • TM-compatible cylinder
  • V3 tappet plate
  • V2 spring guide
  • Spring (for assembly i recommend to use lightest spring possible, as m80 or m90)
    Assembly
    =======
    Last two pictures show parts, as they should be assembled and view of assembled gearbox upper with added hop-up unit.
    Print all parts.
    Glue m3 nuts into top rail and bottom part.
    Take plastic airsoft ak non-boreup cylinder head, remove o-ring and brass tube. Remove support parts of printed head and drill hole for brass tube. Install brass tube and o-ring to printed head.
    Try to assemble all parts with TM-compatible cylinder, piston, ak-type nozzle, ak-type tappet plate, 2-version spring guide (fix it to rear part of gearbox with m5 screw)
    Use dremel or files to ensure smooth move of all movable parts =)

title: Cageless Ball Bearing for 3/16" Balls
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Ball bearing without the need for a cage. But it definetely needs a lot of patience to put it together. I will tweak some minor issues to improve print quality.
It's designed to fit 27 balls in three levels. Probably only two levels would also be easier for putting together, but then the bearing would loose its ability to carry also longitudal load.
Update: it took me two prototypes to figure out the new version. All printing issues should be resolved. I also switched to dimensions for M5 screws, because I had no M3 at hand. By the way: the new installation concept does not need a clockmaker's hand to be assembled :) simply print, put the balls in place and screw together. Update 2: well... still doesn't seem to work. Now the gap is too wide so the balls fall out...

comments.text: I don't see how this isn't a problem. In this configuration the balls scratch on each other with double the speed as they would scratch on a cage. and that on a point contact instead of a bigger area in a cage - probably leading to excessive wear.
comments.author: mechadense

comments.text: considering the resolution: you're not trying to print the balls, are you? because I used 3/16th of an inch nylon balls. (pretty cheap on ebay)
comments.author: tobiaskornmayer

comments.text: you're right: the outer (and inner ring) ring would turn in the opposite direction of the main shaft, but that shouldn't be an issue, should it? :D main problem solver would be a tool to assemble it, since the balls of the inner ring tend to drop in the lower one during assembly, and mess up the spacing.
comments.author: tobiaskornmayer

comments.text:
If the axle turns say anticlockwise and the ring turns clockwise both coaxial sheets of balls turn clockwise thus they can't roll on each other (opposing circumference speed where the balls touch). I tried to solve this with three instead of two layers of different sized rollers here:
Nonsliding Roller Bearing
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:56043
But FDM printer resolution seems insufficient for this endeavor :(
comments.author: mechadense

author: tobiaskornmayer

description.text:
While toying around with options for creating soldered prototype circuits with 3D printing, it occurred to me that the parts could live inside a little cube with their legs dangling outside of the cube for hand soldering. It will take a little bit of artistry to run the wires on this one, however the potential to "grow" these or similar structures onto your print for a morphed-in-place circuit is very attractive.  
The cubes shown in the photo are printed in high temperature PLA which will help resist solder melts and burns somewhat.  If your fingers are too big and clumsy to put the parts in, use needle nose pliers of the type shown in the photo, and / or make the BreadCrumb bigger.  
The history of the BreadBoard goes back to the early radio days when hobbyists would use a small piece of wood as the physical foundation for building a radio circuit.  These "breadboards" evolved until today they are in their current form that we are familiar using.  So it seemed only natural to call these little things "breadcrumbs", though they could be made large or complex if desired.

comments.author: NoahHornberger

comments.text: It is also possible to custom design a 3D printed circuit guide with more features than these breadcrumbs, like posts for wrapping Vdd at the top and Gnd at the bottom, round forms for winding antennae with magnet wire, and planned arrangement of parts for optimal soldering.  There are lots of shapes possible also including flat (booring!), curved, spherical, elliptical, V-shaped or whatever fits in your project.

description.text: This is a evolution of my TomTom Start 60 car mount. It has grown to a universal device mount system with fully parametrized components. Adopts to the dimensions of small (i.e. Xperia Active) to large devices (said TomTom). Create brackets and bars to connect to standard car mount plates, which sell for a few dollars and provide excellent suction mounts. Or use your own mount with a M6 screw hole. Both bar types can be created with this thing, and use the same brackets.

First create the brackets. Make them fit tightly, the brackets are springy, for a firm grip. Then measure from one bracket to the other, outside to outside. This is the device width needed for the bar. The bar has two end stops which hold the brackets and should be placed just outside of the brackets. Select the connector option, either standard connector plate or M6 screw hole, and then go and make...

title: Airsoft electric toy gun - lower gearbox

description.text:
This is a lower part of gearbox for my printed airsoft electric gun project.
Main project hub http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:461896

Parts
=====
You will need:
  • m3 screws and nuts
  • TM-compatible gears and 6-mm bearings
  • TM-compatible antireverse latch and spring
  • Metallic clip for papers
    Assembly
    ===
    Print all parts
    Glue m3 nuts into slots
    Glue right and left parts of "gearside back"
    Assembly all parts with gears and antireverse latch
    Take clip and cut 20-mm long strait piece. Heat it and pierce box to make support for antireverse latch spring.

I want them for a demonstration and to do random stuff (no real airsoft intended) but the gears are way too expensive here for just having some fun or chill... (over 35 u$d the cheapest set)

I updated this file with the new version of the floor tile, which has better visibility and a hole for a magnet. This is a 2x2 wall tile meant to be compatible with OpenForge.
I made this by putting the four floor tile shapes from TheRooster's improved dungeon terrain onto devonjones' floor tiles. The four floor tiles had to be shrunk by half a millimeter in length and breadth in order to fit perfectly in the same dimensions as the OpenForge floor tile. The wall from TheRooster's terrain was then stretched and squashed to be the same size as the walls in devonjones' OpenForge pieces. This thing was made with Tinkercad. title: Zero reference offset spacer for glass plate printing.

description.text: I'm just making my first foray into glass plate printing and I realised I needed to adjust the Z axis zero point to compensate for the thickness of the glass, so here's a little device to do just that.  I designed it for my Wanhao Duplicator 4 which I believe has the same layout as the Makerbot so should work for either.  Nice and orange so I can easily see when it's in place.

The spacer is designed to sit on the 5mm thick vertical perspex plate which activates the Z-axis zero microswitch, tripping it 3mm (the thickness of the glass) earlier than it would without. When you put the glass plate on, just use the handle to lower the spacer down onto the rear plate, behind the Z-axis threaded rod.
I printed this the slow way (vertically) to eliminate the need for bridging across the gap and to give extra strength to the handle.
And my first print onto glass? . . . Smooth and shiny!

author: AndyGadget

description.text: I found myself constantly looking for small boxes to put all my tiny screws, electronic components and other stuff in so I made these small interlocking boxes to solve the problem. They have very thin walls so they are light, economical and quick to print. When you need more boxes, just print them out and snap them to the others. I hope you find use for them and please post a picture if you print them.
I used 1.75 mm ABS, feed rate 60, extruder temp 240 and 10% infill on my Flashforge Creator X.

description.text:
This is a part of bigger project: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:461896
Grip for airsoft electric toy gun project.

Parts
====
  • M3 screws and nuts
  • M8 nut and part of screw
  • Short type motor
  • Wires - thick for main current and thin for controls
  • Spring (ball pen spring fits OK)
  • Micro button (6*7 mm base)
    Assembly
    ====
    Print all parts.
    Carefully remove supports from inner grip (on picture shown grip without support)
    Ensure that all details fit and all movable detail move, than glue two parts of grip.
    Leave 4 long enough wires - 2 thick for main current and 2 thin for control current through button - all of them must be connected to electronic key in frontset.

ABS, 230/110 temps, 70/90 speeds, 0.1 height  
Painting is quite time-consuming, but it pays to invest in surface preparation.  I painted using automotive lacquer (Dupli-Color) and gloss clear.  Wet sanding went quickly with a low grit, moving up to 1000 grit.  Dremel rotary tool helped with the detailed spots.  Blue painter's tape is good for masking, but take care to lay it down flat, and trim precisely with an Xacto knife to create color zones.  Paint in thin layers (I did 4 color, 2 clear) and sand between them (except during clear coats).

2014年9月13日に行われた「有松絞り×デジタルファブリケーション・ワークショップ」で、板締め絞りのための版木をデザインすることから手ぬぐいを制作しました。蛇腹に折りたたまれた布を版木で挟むことで染料が中に浸透することを防ぎパターンを生み出す、板締め絞りという技法です。

description.text:
For Scion FR-S or Subaru BRZ front speakers, to fit Dayton RS180-4 speakers.  This design also adds a rainshield.  
It must be printed in 2 pieces, unless you have a large-format printer.  
Mounting holes were made intentionally small, so drill them out to fit the desired fasteners (I used standard M6 nuts and bolts)

Time to get organized! For years I've had a pair of metal interlocking file stands in a set of wood drawers for holding files. For almost as many years, the plastic brackets that secure them in place have been broken and useless, letting files flop around at will. Today, my girlfriend offered a trade: if I fixed the file cabinet, she would do all of the house cleaning. Needless to say: OFFER ACCEPTED. :) You can tell from the pictures that I've got a long way to go as far as quality settings with the PLA 4043D and MK5. The MK5 puts out plastic FAST and the PLA stays hot for quite a while, allowing it to sag. I'm sure I could improve this with some cool settings, a faster feedrate, lower temp, maybe a fan blowing on the work piece, etc. Instead, I padded out the values for the holes and hollow areas with some multipliers in the .scad file and everything works great!

• Measure out the clip that you're replacing.
  • Update the .scad file (be sure to curse me for the sloppy code) and export STL.
  • Use Pleasant3D or ReplicatorG to center the object in the STL.
  • Slice.
  • Print (x 2).
  • Screw into place.
  • File!

title: Electrolux Vacuum Cleaner Tube Curved Junction

description.text:
I had a problem in the Electrolux ERGOSPACE with the original part that wear out the hook to fix the tube to the Vacuum Cleaner when not used.
The shape is quite complex but I reproduce it similar to the original, adding some concentric ribs to reinforce the junction with the metal tube.

Printed 80% fill (the previus trial was 40% and it work for a couple of months, then my daughter broke it so I made it again with bigger filler rate).
Just replace the original part with the new one: pay attention when remove the original from the head because the rotating mechanism is made using a plastic small rigid ring part yellow colored (2-3 mm wide) that is fixed between the spare part and the intake of the head and must be reused for this component too...
I also suggest to use sandpaper to make more smooth the junction area and some PTFE Grease to lubricate between head and this part before fix them together with the above ring.

title: Mobius Strip Clock for wall or desk

description.text: A desk or wall clock using a mobius strip as the indicator ring.  An attempt to reconcile a 12 hour clock with a 24 hour day.  Uses a standard battery quartz clock movement.  One revolution of the clock hand corresponds to 12 hours, but a second revolution is required to fully traverse the mobius ring.  The two sides of the mobius ring are marked with appropriate hours.

The clock ring will need a little support to print. The two support pieces will not. To use as a wall clock, the smaller hooked support piece is not needed. A little filing and sanding may be needed to get a snug fit between the ring and the main support piece. Also, between the main support and hooked tilt support. If you overdo it, the pieces can be glued together. Bottom of the hooked support may need to be cut to get ideal angle. Example is set so that the movement is at about 45 degrees, the bottom of the mobius ring barely clears the desktop.
Example was printed in ABS with 0.2 mm layers.

comments.text: How do you put markings on "the two sides" of a mobius ring, given that it's a one sided surface?
comments.author: mwm

comments.text: Yes, the markings are actually all on the same side, so let's say the markings are on both opposing faces.

comments.text: In the modeling software i use, Rhinoceroses, there is a command called ApplyDisplacement. This command takes the color values from and image and warps a surface according to the image. The command is meant for adding textures to surfaces for rendering, It can also be called bump mapping. In this case, the color of the surrounding image was displaced much more than the topography making it fairly easy to separate from the desired parts. However, there is no sure way to make the model to a proper scale using this method.

author: fbuenonet

description.text:
Quick Tuner is a guitar string winder designed to interface with common house hold hand tools. This tool is a WORK IN PROGRESS and is untested. I encourage everyone to submit a suggestion or report a problem, if any are encountered. I will revise and update this until it is fully tested or a better competing tool is released. **Current Revision: V1.3
V1.3: Revised Hex bit dimensions. A tester found them to be to big. All SolidWorks models included. WARNING: USING THIS TOOL WITH A HIGH TORQUE/RPM POWER DRILL IS NOT ADVISED. DOING SO CAN RESULT IN DAMAGE TO YOUR GUITAR AND THIS TOOL.

Step 1: Download the variation you desire.
Step 2: Print the tool.
Step 3: Let me know if it works! The drill bit version is intended to be used with a low torque/rpm electric SCREWDRIVER, not to be confused with a POWER DRILL. Quicktuner = String winder base plus attached screwdriver bit.
Quicktuner_base = String winder base with screwdriver bit interface. Hopefully to be used with preexisting long bits. Phillips or Flathead.
Quicktuner_socket_base = String winder base designed to interface with a socket wrench.

description.text:
This is a compact headphone holder.
After several failed attempts at other holders, I made a compact one that actually works great.

• Skeinforge
  • Print
  • Use!
    • NOTE: If there are ANY spots lacking loops (perimeter only), then you need to slice it with a higher density profile. Usage
  • Insert headphones into holes vertically and turn flat to lock them in place.
  • Cross the ends and wrap around the unit (self explanatory).
  • When done wrapping, take the plug and stick it in the little hole, then push into the thin part. Assuming you used Widen, it'll snap quite nicely.

createt with OpenScad, you can change everything.

ratio

What you need:
a piece of 5mm rod
Bearing 685
2x or 4x M2.5 ca 5mm Bolt
2x M3 Setscrew
2x M3 Nuts
2x M3 10mm Bolt
print the case with support
cut M3 thread for the rod and rotor

title: Makerbeam Servo Mount for Modelcraft RS-3

description.text:
A mounting plate for the Modelcraft RS-3 Hobby Servo for mounting it to the Makerbeam miniature T-slot system (or similar profiles).

Helped me a lot with some prototyping stuff.

title: NEMA17 Snapfit 40x40 Fan Mount for Prusa

description.text: My steppers are getting too hot (~50Â°C), so I think is a good idea to install 40x40x10 fans in all of them. With that you get at least 5Â°C less.

First check if your NEMA17 stepper has recessions on corners in order the snapfits to be able to clip it.
The 40x40x10 fan I bought got 2.8mm holes, so I design the part for M2.5. Maybe you need to open the holes for M3.
YouÂ´ll need two M2.5x12 screws and two M2.5 nuts to mount.
I left enough clearance in the snapfit so youÂ´ll need a few finishing in your printed part.
ItÂ´s very light (3,2g) and prints in 26 min.

description.text:
Print this working Gear Toy to teach gear theory and operation to your kids, yourself, or really anyone of any age who is interested in gears.  You'll also find it irresistible to spin the gears around and around as a desktop curio.  
One of these Gear Toy 1's ended up in the hands of my one year old niece, Ava.  It turns out to be one of little Ava's favorite toys!  She even took the big gear to her bed for nite-nite once.  Just the thought of this puts a tear in my eye - you can bet Ava is going to get plenty of 3D printed gear sets from uncle Les as time passes.  
Note:  files fully revised and tested, now optimized for rapid print time and fits on a six inch bed!  
Les

By default the OpenSCAD file generates a printable "plate" consisting of three parts:  the base and two gears.  These are spaced closely and rotated in such a way as to minimize print bed area.  
Use the part variable if the plate is too big for your printer.  The included STL file fits on a 6"x6" bed such as that of a PrintrBot Simple Metal.  
Endjoy!

description.text: This customizeable cuff bracelet is simple and elegant. It is also perfect for further decoration via painting, applying fabric covering, or gluing things onto it.  The STL is for a 60x70 mm bracelet which is pretty average.  Use the customizer if you want to shift the shape or size around.  Note writs are oval not round!  Scaling the STL will also work, particularly for minor adjustments.

No support is needed to print this.  You may need to print it in ABS if you need to stretch it much to put it on. Print it with a lot of infill to make sure it is nice and strong.  There may be some deformation on the lower curved surface.  It can be cleaned up easily with a little sanding or filing.  If you don't want to use the customizer, you could always just enlarge or shrink the STL.  
Note the sizes on the STL are for the outer maximum diameter of the bracelet.

description.text:
Create smoothly curved vessels by interactively adjusting the size and position of constraints on the container's diameter. A Bezier curve is fit to pass through these key points, forming the object's profile. The profile is rotated around the central axis to form the vase.
You can adjust the resolution for a smooth or polygonal appearance. You can also select whether to generate a solid object suitable for printing in "spiral vase" mode or a hollow object with set wall thickness.
For a different approach to creating smoothly curved objects in Customizer, check out my previous Bezier vase thing (it uses the polygon drawing widget as a crude control point input method).
Part of my Customizable Containers collection.
I printed the beziervase-solid.stl sample file in black PLA at 0.3 mm layer height with 4 perimeters, 5 bottom layers, and 0 top/bottom/infill.

We needed a hair grip that could be customised for my sister to wear for her wedding. This is the 3D comb part. The back edge is thinner that any we could buy and has the addition of holes to thread decorative parts through.
photos attached of the printed clip, the finished clip and it in use at my sisters wedding.

I printed this on my up printer at 0.2mm layers using clear material. To make it slide smoothly I treated it with acetone vapour, but a good sand using fine grain sand paper (200+ grade) between the teeth should be enough.
If you use acetone allow plenty of time to re-harden to make sure the teeth are strong enough. I left mine for 2 days before it was hard enough.
Have fun

title: Lego Heroica Boss Door and Switch

description.text: If you like my work I hope you'll consider supporting me on Pateron: https://www.patreon.com/3DPrintingProfessor Subscribe to me on YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/user/mrjoesays My children's favorite game is Heroica. But recently we played a level where it became apparent we need another way to prevent someone from rushing the boss to win. So I made this, a door and a cover for a lever to match it. Now the players have to go to the switch before they open the door. And if they don't then no one else can progress to the end. It still needs some work game play wise but it looks cool. Part of this was made in Tinkercad by my son (with some help). https://tinkercad.com/things/g7UpLdTHD9k-lego-boss-switch

I needed pliers to get the switch into the skull. We've still got to build a base for it that we all like. it's a work in progress.
Remember if you're printing in ABS that you need to scale up to account for shrinkage. I found a scale factor of 1.02 worked perfect.

title: 1U Rackmount Brackets - under a table, desk, or counter

description.text:
This is a very basic bracket that will allow you to mount a 1U rack mountable piece of equipment. I have 7 monitors so this switch under my desk allows me to turn each monitor on/off individually. Print with supports.   
I recommend 25% fill or higher depending on how heavy your equipment is.  
There are no holes in this bracket, I used a drill. Use 4 screws per bracket to secure it under your table, desk or counter.   
You may need to rotate the model first. This is a work in progress, I hope someone finds it useful.

I used 25% fill; use more or less depending on how heavy your equipment is.  
There are no holes in this bracket, I used a drill. Use 4 screws per bracket to secure it under your table, desk or counter.   
You may need to rotate the model first. This is a work in progress, I hope someone finds it useful.

author: Jussybro

description.text:
Very simple printable guide for a 608zz bearing. Idea is that the gt2 belt ( or whatever ) just wedges into the grove of 2 of these guys.
Intended to be very thin and just enough to let the belt have something to keep it from slipping around. I added just a tiny bit of fudge - no need for tight tolerance here imo!
Tweaked the original design a bit, added a v2. I found that with the original spacing the 608 was just a little too loose on the bearing so now its exact. Its a tight fit, but even in PLA I was able to get the bearing on.
Also found that I needed a total of 9mm so I created one at 5.5 and one at 3.5. Also made the ridge just a little taller ( well, technically the diameter of the cylinder smaller ;) ) I made a slightly different version of my idler guide. I wanted to play with using a 625 instead of a 608. The OD is 16, so using this on my openbeam printer should result in a better fit and not rub on the upper rail as its doing now. I kinda hacked the parameterization. I generated a few arrays and just pick one, then the rest is or should be done for you. I have yet to print the parameterized version so use at your own risk ;)

slice it, hit print. I chose 10% infill but probably could have just used 0 as the diameter of this part is so small there won't be infill!
You need two for a complete cover. The height will be the same as the 608

author: Jussybro

description.text: One thing very handy is to be able to fine adjust the Z axis microswitch. I miss this funcionality in Ecksbot, I bet most Prusa Mendel donÂ´t have it. This is a very simple ideia how to make this Z fine adjustment.

• Print the part
  • Open M4 screw in the vertical hole of the part
  • Attach 1x M4x25 allen screw in the part (as seen in picture). The nut is optional
  • Position the part in your Prusa, mark and make 2x Ã˜2.5mm holes and make M3 screw on them
  • Use 2x Allen M3x16 screws to fix the part
  • Lower your Z axis microswitch to the new position

  • Enjoy your new adjustment!

  • I attached the Solidworks 2012 part in case you want to modify it

comments.text: Yes, I´ve sent this improvement suggestion to Eckertech and they´ve included it.
comments.author: pauloblank

comments.text: I hate to render your item useless, but the Ecksbot already has this feature.  There is a hole in the block already for exactly this purpose.  It is on the other side of where you put yours, right near the bearings.  If you spin your Z switch around to the other side of the slide rod, the hole in the red block will line up with the switch.  You just need to put a small bolt though it.  An M3 I think.

comments.text: Sorry, my mistake.  I see that yours was an older one before Eckertech added the hole for this bolt.  Good for you :)

author: Jussybro

description.text:
Simply some of the Bottle Moustache converted to be able to print on a Makerbot. 
Print them out for you Halloween parties so your beers don\'t get mixed up.
Figured I should print some up for our Marina Halloween Party and should share with the rest of you.

Some are rotated since my build platform prints closer to the edge that way. I had to crop one down to fit on the build platform and not all of the original Mustaches are converted. 
I numbered them in order they came in the original svg and added a descriptor on what kind of Mustache I thought they where.
All Mustaches are 1.5mm high. They may need to be thicker to work right. I have not tested them yet since my makerbot is over at my art space and isn\\\\'t easily available until tomorrow. Hopefully ready for Halloween parties this Sunday.
someone out there should mix up the ones from last year to make them into beer fobs... or make them parametric... hmmm.... me needs to figure that one out.

comments.text: We had them injection molded. But unfortunately we don't make them any more. They were called Pop's 'Stache. Laser cutting was how we made our original prototypes. Snapped way to easily. Our product was made from high density poly Ethelyn.

author: lilwheatos

title: Printrbot free-spinning fillament spool holder (using 608 bearing)

description.text:
I wanted a free-spinning spool holder that mounted onto my Printrbot Simple Metal, and one that didn't take a lot of material to print. This design uses a single 608 skateboard bearing (readily available online) to allow the spool to spin freely, so the extruder doesn't have to do any unnecessary extra work overcoming friction. I'll be adding more spool sizes in the future. If you need anything, please let me know the spool hole size (diameter) that you need, and the brand of your spool. The current list of available sizes are:
  • 32mm
  • 38mm
  • 48mm
  • 50mm
  • 54mm
  • 55mm
    • Depending on printer settings, you may have to adjust the dimensions to get the right fit - the bearing and the Printrbot z-guides should fit into the holes fairly tightly and not come apart easily. Update: I uploaded the Sketchup file so you can make your own adjustments. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1OufJ8LPwbs

You will need either frame.stl (straight version) or frame_v2.stl (better, angled version), and one of the spool holders that fit your spool.  Measure the diameter of the hole of your filament spool, and select one that is equal to or slightly smaller than the hole.  The Hatchbox spools that I currently use has a 32mm diameter hole, and so I would need the spool_32mm.stl.  You only need to print one spool holder per spool.  
If you have a spool with a hole size not covered by the provided files, feel free to adapt the design, or let me know.  
In addition to the 3D printed parts, you will need a 608 bearing.  These are standard bearings used in skateboards, and also in hobby parts, so you should be able to easily find one on eBay, or via another online retailer, or a skate shop.  
Once you have printed out the parts and found a 608 bearing, you can assemble the spool holder.  Everything friction-fits together.  If things are too tight or loose, you can adjust the scaling on your print, or load modify the 3D file, or DIY-it using sandpaper/glue.

comments.text:
I made one holder and both reels. My filaments are of a different size so I resized the reel. Constructed four reels with my diameters. As I have not learned enough to modify the interior diameter, I used tie-wraps. It worked well for my 51 and 53mm reels but was sloppy on my 55mm reel. Will probably glue the tie-wraps into the reel later. Fasinating project for this novice experimenter. Thanks Yuan!
P.S. Using PrintrBot Metal Simple with Filaments from three different companies. I really like to experiment!

title: Gallifreyan Coins
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Coins come in two flavors; In and Out.  Pick which ever you prefer.  
Your slicer may have issues with the thin walls of Out versions, either narrow the extrusion diameter or use a smaller orifice nozzle.  
Made using Inkscape to generate a svg and Tinkercad to extrude it into 3 dimensions and add a base.

Update 3: Moar Coins!  Also modified my method, so the old coins are retired.  If you really want them, they will be in the V1 zip file.  The new method gets rid of most of the circles connecting to dots issue that was in V1.  
New Coins - Master, Rassilon, Omega, River Song, Doctor, Thingiverse.  
Update 2: Uploaded another coin. One on left says "Doctor Who", the one on the right says "Thingiverse".  
Update: Uploaded a copy from my harddrive instead of using the Tinkercad hosted one.  Should be able to download now.

Leaf patterns to laser cut, super back to school project for kids!

I used recycled corrugated cardboard and tempera paint for this kid's project. Daub paint with a piece of recycled plastic bag, dabbing paint like decorative sponge or rag painting techniques for walls. Plastic or Styrofoam plates hold paint colors well. Be careful of sharp edges: so finger painting is no recommended for corrugated cardboard.
Finger painting might be safe for laser cut cereal boxes (chipboard food packaging) or poster board. Also, have children write their name on the back before you paint so they can get their leaf back when you change classroom decorations.
I used a tip from Buzzfeed.com "37 Teacher Hacks" to hang the leaves. Put a strip of blue painter's tape on the wall, put a line of hot glue on the blue painter's tape and stick your leaf up. Humidity will create some warping over time. Hey, it's just cardboard...

My wife needed star shaped buttons, so this is the result.
The openscad file has a few parameters, the shape could even be changed.

Printed on a prusa I2, sliced with Slic3r, 100% infill, 0.3 mm layers.
I had to re drill the holes after printing.

Everyone wants to be a MakerBot. Here is how to live your dream - become a MakerBot today!

Step 1: Find a Box
I used a chair box I found in the Botcave because we've been hiring so many people and getting chairs for them. But you can use whatever box you want. This one happened to be the perfect size for a MakerBot costume.
Step 2: Gather Supplies
The foundations for a good MakerBot costume are box cutters, scissors, and tape. Cutting out the walls of the box was easiest with box cutters. I used the scissors to cut pieces of brown paper I salvaged from the recycling bin to coat the box with. I used the tape to hold the paper in place. 
Step 3: Paper your Box
Covering the box with brown paper was the most time consuming part of this job. It took over an hour. An alternative solution is to turn the box inside out, which would require cutting down one of the sides and potentially compromising its structural integrity.
Step 4: Get Your M On
I printed out an M on brightly colored paper and used an exacto knife to cut it out. There was no time to spell out â€œMakerBot Industries,â€ or to preserve the bump in the front wall of the Cupcake for the M. I was proud just to have a bright-colored, nicely printed MakerBot logo.
Step 5: Bling Your MakerBot
Thereâ€™s no doubt about it â€“ people are impressed by LED lights. Feel free to decorate your MakerBot with circuit boards, plastic parts, and anything else you find lying around. But if thereâ€™s one thing that will make the costume, itâ€™s those bright little LEDs.
Step 6: Accesorize
Any good MakerBot costume is all about the final touches. I gathered some ABS, put some blue tape on my belly, wielded an extruder, appropriated a freshly printed object and taped it to my belly to mimic a MakerBot object platform.
Done!

title: New Frame for the 200QX Quad Copter

description.text: No, not another Quad copter but instead a means to stop buying fragile frames (not crash proof).  Print these parts up (I color code the arms to the LED colors for the daytime orientation.  The glowing "lamps" are clear ABS (translucent after printing).  The arms are 60mm long 5.5mm diameter hollow carbon fiber rods CA'd or epoxied into the arm ends.  Make sure they are level with each other to prevent a tilted motor from yawing the quad.  The standard 200QX battery Velcro's to the top plate.  Save the screws from the original body as these are used to mount the landing gear.  I used wax string to tie the motor connectors / wires on both sides of the arms as a strain relief and protect the wires from being tugged and broken.  This is the number one reason why the FETs on the motor controllers burnout; broken wires internal to the motor!.  Finished weight printed at a 40% fill comes in almost identical to the original model.  Tie wraps are used to mount the arms to the body.  These are designed to fail before the body parts.  There are tie wrap mounts on the bottom for FPV / camera gear if you so decide.  Flies, flips, and goes inverted as good as the original.

title: Easy-Print Master Ball
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
You can print the lid assembled or in pieces.
If you print in pieces you need to use the new inner ring. Otherwise you can use all original parts form the Easy Print Pokeball which have been mirrored here for convenience.

For printing in pieces:

  • 1) Print one outer shell lid main, one outer shell lid m, and two outer shell lid bump pieces.
    2) Cut out the supports inside the M of the outer shell lid main.
    3) When installing the bumps make sure the curved part is toward the top of the lid.
    4) Print the new inner ring and then assemble the rest as normal.
    For printing the assembled lid:

  • 1) Print the outer shell lid assembled
    2) Print the rest of the pieces from the original easy print pokeball and assemble as normal

A solution to a problem you didn't know you had...
Black panels too boring?
Don't want the LCD hole in your panels?
Bulge in the middle making your eye twitch?
Want to make custom panels, but don't want to deal with the pain of measuring those holes?
UPDATE: Confirmed fitment and uploaded models for front lower side panels that hook over the bottom frame bar. These take a little longer and need support to print, but they attach very securely.
UPDATE2: Front center panel looks good. Posted the blank plate model. I personalized mine, but the font isn't 100% free so not posting that model. If there's interest I can post one with a different font.
UPDATE3: Center panel v2 should solve a couple of issues. A third bottom rail support was added to prevent buzzing, and the supports have been changed slightly to hopefully ease removal of support material. If you printed the v1 center panel, just add 1-2 layers of painters tape between the lower bar and the panel to prevent buzzing.
UPDATE4: v2 of the left and right front panels. updated similarly to the v2 center panel.
UPDATE5: Working on dioder add-ons. First item up is an IKEA dioder controller mount that clips to the front panel. Next will be a panel that has standoffs to mount the power supply. I discovered that I'm not happy with the hole alignment for the panels, though. I should be releasing new versions soon.
TODO: I plan to add panels for the sides and back. Once I've got these dialed in, the next plan is to design a printable enclosure. If someone wants to tweak this stuff for the Rigibot small, feel free.

Porta jugos
This object is a structure that you can do 3D string art not just 2D string art.

First, I wanted to have a solid 3d printer for as cheap as possible. So I choose the model mendel 90 because there is not that much printed parts and the body is made of mdf and I'm used to work with it.
So looking at the plans and "vitamins" I realized it was going to be hard to make it for cheap: as I am in Canada (Québec, sorry for my English!) It was hard to find metric stuff. So I decided to work on plans to make it with imperial stuff for rods, bolts, nuts. etc.
Before I get started, I also removed from the original design every thing that is not essential to get printing. This printer can be built for less than 300$.
So here are my main changes:
  • I used 5/16 smooth rods instead of 8mm (7,94mm)
  • I used lm8uuaj: ajustable linear bearings
    For this reson, every bearing mount is designed to be screwable. So you screw the bolt and nut just enough for it to be stable but not too much so it can move freely.
  • I redesigned the extruder to fit 6-32 screws and be more solid (I'm not the first to do that, but...)
  • I worked on the x carriage to find a good optional way to easily install the extruder with a bowden tube, or not!
    Also I fixed the j-head style fixation for hot end directly on the x carriage so that if there is a jam, you can work on it just by removing the extruder or the bowden adaptor, but still solidly installed on the x carriage.
  • I changed the place where the back pannels are so that it protects your psu and ramps. But it also allows you to put some more plastic spools.
  • I simplified all the wiring that was so complex on the original mendel 90. now you can just use normal wires with tie wrap
    And the beauty of that desing: you can (have) to use your imagination to make your own printer. I mean for mdf panels, cut the size you want, same thing for rods. With these printed parts you could build a 24x24x24 inch 3d printer if you wanted. Just use longer rods and bigger mdf pannels!
    "Bowden" and "lcd case" are'nt essential to make that thing work.
    • Some improvements to come:
    -a little modification to the extruder so that the gears are easyer to align.
    -Add end stop switch bracket on both sides (x motor and x idler) so that you can chose on wich side you want to put it.
    Add a plastic plate to glue hot end plugs on x carriage. En passant, si t'es à Québec et que ça t'intéresse, j'en ai quelques unes à vendre de ces machines!!!

You can inspire yourself from the official mendel90 reprap page...
http://reprap.org/wiki/Mendel90_Build_Manual
But understand that there will be several changes!
I used
ramps 1.4
lm8uuaj bearings and 5/16 rods
J head style hot end

6-32 bolts and nuts of many length
2 meter of timing strap with metal pulley
8x8 heated bed
lot of patience!
I'll add videos of assembling as soon as possible!
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hbSo27Q2qHo

comments.text: Aren't you worried about the safety of using plastic from the 3D printer with hot coffee? I mean there is a lot of perspectives on this, just FYI.. Like bacteria in the small microscopic holes in the printed object, that you can't wash out so easily (steaming it would melt the plastic and you mentioned a milk ramp so yeah, milk is no good if left somewhere, that's why I hate full-automatic coffee makers, you would have to clean the milk pipes daily.. Also the leftovers after printing with the nozzle, can leave some trace material on the object, unless it is stainless steel nozzle.. And then there is the material you print with itself, like if it is used cold, PLA should be safe for health, ignoring the bacteria and nozzle things.. But as far as I know ABS is a different story.. I am not some bacteria-feared weirdo, just read a lot about this recently :D Maybe you will find it interesting ;)

description.text:
This is a curtain rod holder that will allow you to place curtains over your sliding door blinds. The wooden rods can be cut to any length, in this case I cut them to 7 inches which is enough to cover the installed blinds.
The sliding door I have is in my bed room and I prefer to keep my room dark especially in the early morning. The blinds I have work but they don’t do enough to keep the bright sunlight out. I created these curtain rod holders to fit over the blinds and hold up a pair of black out curtains.

PLA .2mm layer, 10% infill
3D printed parts:
2 - curtain_rod_holder_base pieces.
1 - curtain_rod_holder_hook.
Hardware needed:
1 - Round head screw 8-32 x 1/2 with nut (Lowes Item#: 57843 Model#: 491288).
1 - Butterfly toggle bolt 3/16 x 2 (Lowes Item#: 326601 Model #: 7124).
1 - 5/16 x 48 poplar dowel - cut to your desire. I used 7in to clear my blinds.
1 - Strong adhesive to secure the 4 wooden rods to the holders base.
1 - 5/8 Wood Boring drill bit.
Base and wood rods installation.
  • Drill a hole with the 5/8 wood boring drill bit in the desired location.
  • Insert the 3/16 x 2 toggle bolt into the center of the curtain_rod_holder_base. Place and screw the butterfly clip onto the very end/tip of the screw.
  • Pinch the butterfly clips together and insert them into the 5/8 hole. Insert until they completely open on the other side of the drywall and you can no longer remove it.
  • Hold and pull the curtain_rod_holder_base towards you and screw the 3/16 x 2 screw. As you screw it in it will slowly get closer to the wall. Screw until it is flat and secure against the wall.
  • Apply a strong adhesive to glue the four wooden rods into each of the holders. Let your adhesive dry.
    Repeat steps 1- 6 for each holder.
    Hook installation.
  • Take one curtain_rod_holder_base and one curtain_rod_holder_hook and place them back to back.
  • Insert 1 nut into the center of the curtain_rod_holder_hook.
  • Insert the 8-32 X 1/2 screw into the center of curtain_rod_holder_base and screw them together firmly.
  • Place a generous amount of adhesive into each of the holders of the curtain_rod_holder_base and insert it onto the four wooden rods from step 5 in the “Base and wood rods installation”.
    Let the adhesives dry properly or the wooded rods will slide out once the curtain rod and curtains are installed. Make sure to glue both ends of the wooden rods. Check the manufactures recommended drying times and follow them.
    Black out curtains are heavy so make sure to use at least 3 of these curtain rod holders to properly distribute the weight.
